90s Comeback Bands and Pubescent Nostalgia: The Nouse Reading and Leeds Festival Guide 2010

Ah Reading and Leeds festival. You are the obnoxious, pubescent, lairy younger brother to Glastonbury

Matisyahu

Having just released third LP 'Light' in the UK, Matisyahu talks to Mia de Graaf (Thumbnail credit Matisyahu relaxingwith his beard)

Future Sounds

(Thumbnail credit Ghostpoet)

Trampled Under Hoof

Tom Killingbeck cross-examines cosmic collective Chrome Hoof

Slam Dunk Festival

First up was <strong>Random Hand</strong> on the Vans stage; guitars and a trombone literally never sounded so good

Lady Gaga

Not many shows can claim to begin before they even start, but Lady Gaga's show was destined to be a spectacle from the beginning

Nouse Playlist

As the three terrifyingly brief years of university come to a close, wave goodbye to these parting classics before heading into the 'real world' ...

Stone Circles and Pyramids: The Nouse Glastonbury Guide 2010

By James Bithell

At the end of this week, as is tradition, a lucky few York students will be migrating to the Glastonbury Festival of Contemporary Performing Arts to be caked in mud and faeces quasi-ritualistically, probably as part of a post-finals bacchanal

Label Spotlight # 2: Upset the Rhythm

Born as a promoter out of frustration with the London music scene in 2003, Upset the Rhythm has since have gained a well-founded reputation for supporting the most exciting underground acts around

Philadelphia Grand Jury

Interview with Simon (lead vocals and guitar) of <em>Philadelphia Grand Jury</em> (Thumbnail credit Calvin, Berkfinger (aka Simon) and MC Bad Genius (aka Joel), Image: Philadelphia Grand Jury Press Shot)

Ice Sea Dead People

Interview with Craig (lead vocals and guitar) of <em>Ice Sea Dead People</em> (Thumbnail credit David, Craig, Jamie, Photo: Lucy Johnston)

Future Sounds

First up are the Philadelphia Grand Jury, otherwise known as the Philly Jays. Formed in Australia, they've recently set up shop in trendy Shoreditch in London and have set out upon a UK assault, including a well received slot at Live at Leeds earlier this month (Thumbnail credit Philadelphia Grand Jury)

International Relations

If traipsing through muddy English fields doesn't quite appeal to you, why not go abroad for your festival fix?

Times New Viking

Stereo on Gillygate is fast establishing itself as the most hard-working and exciting new venue in town. A stream of bands from the local area and much further afield never seem to stop wheeling through its doors

Pavement

For anyone who was born too late to see Pavement in their prime, subsequently becoming a fan was a slightly depressing prospect, knowing the opportunity to see them live might never arise

Nouse Playlist

Fuck the tent, clean clothes and deodorant, just remember to slam these festival beasts on your outdated portable CD player and blast them at passers-by without mercy

Hard to Beat

By James Bithell

The 'All Tomorrow's Parties' series has become notorious - a crazy diamond in the crown of British festivals

Intrepid indie ecologists Stornoway

UK indie has had many past dalliances with the pastoral; most recently British Sea Power with their foliage obsession and appearance on Countryfile. But Stornoway's sound - whimsical pop-folk that suggests sun-dappled meadows and rolling dales - is backed up with professional experience in ecology (Thumbnail credit Stornoway enjoying a post-hike sing-song)

Future Sounds

If we haven't rubbed it in your face enough yet, this weekend was 'Live at Leeds'

True Sounds of Liberty

Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to the only boys wearing drainpipes in Kabul

Paloma Faith

aloma Faith's star is soaring. Following memorable performances on 'Later... with Jools Holland' and the considerable vitriol aimed at her outrageous outfits in Heat magazine, Faith is closing her first headlining tour in London

LCD Soundsystem

The O2 is rammed full of a heady mixture of towering bald men and miniature indie kids, which shows the broad spectrum of James Murphy's appeal

The Alternative Glee Soundtrack

Here are just a few of the tracks that should have made it into the New Directions repertoire

The Loss and Curse of Reverence

By James Bithell

The Norwegian Black Metal scene counts as one of the few localized happenings in music history to truly infiltrate the international consciousness; like DC hardcore, Detroit techno, or Jamaican reggae, it was a case of a few influencing many

Citywide Curfew by Officer Kicks

If you are unfamiliar with London-based Officer Kicks, you can be forgiven: in their own biography they declare: "if success was measured by fame or money then we would be in the bottom of a barrel marked 'invalid' and my musical life (all 10 years of it) would be labelled the 'LONG void'"

Judging An Album By Its Cover

By James Bithell

Recently, album art standards seem to have reached an all-time low

Exposure for Exposure

Parent groups take note, and set your disapproval levels to moral outrage. Nudity is making a revival of sorts in music videos, not that it ever took an extended leave, mind

The Seven Labels of Hercules

By James Bithell

It may seem that the record label's future is uncertain - the unremitting, globalizing, barrier crushing effect of the internet on the power of independent music means that many new artists will, and can, simply self-release their music

We Have Band

We Have Band, a fast-emerging trio on the indie music scene, have gone from strength to strength in little over a year

Electronic indie dancefloor shakers Passion Pit

Three years ago, college student Michael Angelakos recorded a couple of songs on his laptop as a Valentine's gift for his girlfriend. As this home-made EP casually changed a few hands, the DIY electro-pop tracks soon began to generate some major hype, at first through word of mouth and then the blogosphere (Thumbnail credit Passion Pit relax at home)
